title: Obedience is for Dogs!
description:
The more time I spend with my son, the more I realize how disgusting and irresponsible the Christian message is for humanity. And how destructive it is for individuals.

Dying for people, if that‚Äôs what Jesus‚Äô self righteous suzy-side was, is WEAK. 

You want to know what strength is?
LIVING FOR SOMEONE.

Living for someone, being there for them, EVERY TIME they call for you. Being there EVERY DAY.
None of this "hiddenness is good" because of "reason, reason, reason."

Living for someone means:

Making them breakfast. 
Changing their diapers. 
Playing with them. 
Holding them. 
Listening to them.
Not being silent.
Pretty much being the opposite of the example we find in the writings about the supposed Christian God. 

F the Jesus and the donkey he rode in on. 
He is weak. 

We who reject human sacrifice as a means to pay for our responsibilities are strong. 

To god-men and their self-proclaimed representatives, I say, ‚Äúf@#K you, I won‚Äôt do what you tell me!‚Äù


Hey All! 

If you've wondered where I've been, well, raising a baby and writing novel. 
But daunting tasks.

I can't do much YouTube stuff these days, but I'm still around, still check out comments, and I hope to do a little more with updates on Stephen and the amazing adventure of being one of his parents.

FYI: He has the BEST mom in the universe. She is amazing and he's a fortunate kid.

The video that I made in response to the ahistorical nonsensical (and racist, in my view) claims of Mike  @InspiringPhilosophy and Than @ExploringReality responding to @maklelan  be found here:

https://youtu.be/unoMvayYG3s

Essentially Mike and Than argue that Black Americans should be thankful to Christians for "ending slavery" and that "Christianity" was the primary and driving force behind abolition. 

Of course in order to sell this racist bigoted garbage, they have to lie, gaslight, and pretend to be intellectuals. 

Don't buy it. 

We can see they're lying by simply going to primary documents and reading about history, something the know the vast majority of their sheeple audience simply will not bother with doing. 

In my research I discovered even I was saying things that were wrong because I've been so conditioned by American schooling and Christian teaching, for example Wilberforce, when he argued for "abolition" the thing he was arguing for was the end of the transatlantic slave trade. 

Abolition to Wilberforce was ending the slave trade, the word was used to argue for the end of the slave trade, not the ending of slavery, something he did want, but didn't fight for directly, as he knew Christians would not end slavery without going incrementally. 

The other realization during my studies, and I've barely scratched the surface, is that it was Quakers who were the first to argue for abolition (and they influenced people like Wilberforce). 

So saying "Christianity" ended slavery is like saying Christianity did X --- X being anything like teaching that the wine really turns to the blood of Jesus or that proper worship happens on Saturday morning or any issue that Christians are divided on. 

See?

You don't say "Christians teach that speaking in tongues is an important part of worship and a sign of the indwelling of the Holy Spirit," you say that "Pentecostals" teach this thing, so likewise, if you're going to be accurate, you cannot say, "Christians ended slavery."

Or that "Christianity" was the primary force for abolition.

You must say something like "Quakers were instrumental in the abolition movement."

And if you want to be really accurate, just add, "and they were fighting a Christian majority, most other denominations in fact, who believed and taught slavery was God's design and  not a sin." 

Christians today who rightfully hate slavery are in opposition to most Christians in most of history as well as the clear teachings in their own Bible.

The other realization during my studies, and I've barely scratched the surface, is that it was Quakers who were the first to argue for abolition (and they influenced people like Wilberforce). 

So saying "Christianity" ended slavery is like saying Christianity did X --- X being anything like teaching that the wine really turns to the blood of Jesus or that proper worship happens on Saturday morning or any issue that Christians are divided on. 

See?

You don't say "Christians teach that speaking in tongues is an important part of worship and a sign of the indwelling of the Holy Spirit," you say that "Pentecostals" teach this thing, so likewise, if you're going to be accurate, you cannot say, "Christians ended slavery."

Or that "Christianity" was the primary force for abolition.

You must say something like "Quakers were instrumental in the abolition movement."

And if you want to be really accurate, just add, "and they were fighting a Christian majority, most other denominations in fact, who believed and taught slavery was God's design and  not a sin." 

Christians today who rightfully hate slavery are in opposition to most Christians in most of history as well as the clear teachings in their own Bible.

title: @BraxtonHunter Admits: Different Dad, Different Outcome. Thus, free will is an illusion...
description:
https://www.patreon.com/c/michaelbeverly
Help Support the Fight Against Bigotry! 
#exchristian #freewill #christian 

Braxton admits he has "no idea" how his life would have been different if:
"I hadn't had that kind of a father."

So, if that's true, and it sure seems like it's true, then Braxton is admitting that the kind of father you have determines whether you're likely to be a Christian or a Jew or evil or good or anything....since he does say, "no idea." 

"No idea" means to me, "no idea," and thus the possibilities are endless.

Unless Braxton means by "no idea" that he actually has "some idea," for instance, if he argues he'd still have been a Christian, then he's essentially arguing for determinism.

If, however, he admits that by "no idea" he means "no idea" then he's admitting that whether you're saved or damned is sort of like a roulette wheel, i.e. get a good dad, go to heaven, get a bad dad, go to hell, which is also determinism, no? 

I  think Braxton has to rethink his views and either change his mind or take back his claim that he has "no idea" how his life would have turned out with a different daddy.

Let me know in the comments what I'm missing if you disagree.

We have to get smarter if we want to grow our numbers.

My response is that we are growing our numbers, but not through capitulation and unity and hand-holding, but by aggressively arguing for reality over fantasy.

Mike Jones of Inspiring Sophistry made an appeal to atheists in a community post.

He wants us to shut up and stop trying to "deconvert" Christians.

Sounds like he's aware he's losing this battle.

In a world of "not ironic" it's the opposite for me, at least, on the atheist side of the aisle, I want Christian apologists like Mike Jones to keep talking. The more they speak, in their excuses, lies, gas lighting, bigotry, hatred, and illogical and dumb arguments, the more they help Christians who are asking questions and seeking truth to deconstruct.

I could never help as many Christians leave the faith than Mike Jones could, can, and does! 

"Keep talking and making videos, Mike Jones," I'd say to him. "You're doing a great job helping people see the shallowness and ugliness and hatefulness of Christianity. Good job, brother, don't stop making content." 

Of course, his appeal to people like myself to shut up and be quiet and to stop making content only further motivates us to continue.

Oh the irony must burn, or I suppose maybe he's too dense to see that? 

In either case, I'm enjoying making content to fight Christian hate and I'll continue to do so as long as it's fun and entertaining for me.

Thanks to those who support the channel!

@B.S._Lewis joins me to review some of the antics and craziness of Christian apologist, Katlin Sias, who's learned to master the art of engagement with Shorts.

With 3.42 MILLION subs on YT (as of this being published) Katlin is surely doing something right in terms of engagement and stickiness.

But is he selling his soul for riches and fame? 

Does Jesus, if He actually exists, really want apologists doing this kind of blantant commericalism? Pushing obviously fabricated stories as "proof" that Jesus is real? 

I don't think so.

Join me and B.S. Lewis in condeming this kind of manipulative behavior that is aimed at young believers.

title: Building. Supporting. Caring. Black Nonbelievers.
description:
#skeptism #deconstruction #blacknonbelievers
https://www.patreon.com/michaelbeverly

A chat with Mandisa Thomas about her mission, work, hopes for the future and how others can step up to help.

Black Nonbelievers (BN) is a 501 c3 non-profit organization. Headquartered in the Atlanta area, they connect with other Blacks (and allies) who are living free of religion and might otherwise be shunned by family and friends by providing a caring, friendly, and informative community.

Instead of accepting dogma, they determine truth and morality through reason and evidence.

The mission of Black Nonbelievers is to:
‚Ä¢ Provide secular fellowship.
‚Ä¢ Nurture and support nonbelievers in "coming out" (ie, open identification).
‚Ä¢ Encourage pride in nonreligious identities.
‚Ä¢ Educate the public on the history and current state of nonbelief in the Black community.
‚Ä¢ Organize events and charitable causes.

Website: https://blacknonbelievers.org/

YouTube channel:

@BlackNonbelieversInc 

My links can be found here:
https://michaelsbeverly.com/

description:

From wiki:
Cryonics is the low-temperature freezing  and storage of human remains, with the speculative hope that resurrection may be possible in the future.

Robin Dale Hanson is an associate professor of economics at George Mason University and a former research associate at the Future of Humanity Institute of Oxford University.

His blog, Overcoming Bias can be found here:
https://www.overcomingbias.com/

More info here:
https://mason.gmu.edu/~rhanson/bio.html

From Wiki:
He is known for his work on idea futures and markets, and he was involved in the creation of the Foresight Institute's Foresight Exchange and DARPA's FutureMAP project. He invented market scoring rules like LMSR (Logarithmic Market Scoring Rule) used by prediction markets such as Consensus Point (where Hanson is Chief Scientist), and has conducted research on signalling. He also proposed the Great Filter hypothesis.

Books:

Elephant in the Brain: Hidden Motives in Everyday Life

As mentioned in the video, Jennifer Knust is part of the New Insights into the New Testament 2024 virtual two-day conference put on by Bart Erhman.

If you sign up for the conference through my link, you‚Äôll be helping to support my channel which I greatly appreciate!

https://michaelsbeverly--ehrman.thrivecart.com/nint-2024-standard/

In this video we discuss her book, Unprotected Texts: The Bible's Surprising Contradictions About Sex and Desire

This book is currently in Kindle Unlimited (at the time of uploading):

https://www.amazon.com/Unprotected-Texts-Bibles-Surprising-Contradictions/dp/0061725390

About my guest, from Duke's website:

Jennifer Knust is a scholar of religion who specializes in early Christian history and the religions of the ancient Mediterranean.

Author of To Cast the First Stone: The Transmission of a Gospel Story(with Tommy Wasserman, Princeton 2018), Unprotected Texts: The Bible‚Äôs Surprising Contradictions about Sex and Desire (HarperONE 2011), and Abandoned to Lust: Sexual Slander and Ancient Christianity (Columbia 2005), she studies early Christian texts, their contexts, and their receptions from multiple angles, with a particular focus on rhetoric and gendered discourse. 

Her numerous articles, book chapters, and edited books address the materiality of texts, the intersection of Christian practices with other ancient religions, and the ethics of interpretation in ancient as well as contemporary contexts.

title: Understanding Plant Evolution w/ Dr. Karl Niklas
description:
#evolution #plantbiology #plantbiomechanics 

Help support the channel here:
https://www.patreon.com/michaelbeverly

Dr. Karl J. Niklas joins me to talk about plant biology (botany) specifically about plant evolution, plant biomechanics, and evolutionary biology in general. 

Karl J. Niklas is The Liberty Hyde Bailey Professor of Plant Biology emeritus in the School of Integrative Plant Science, Cornell University. 

His research is in plant biophysics and evolution, with a particular focus on the evolution of biomechanics, complexity, and multicellularity.

He has written over 480 peer-reviewed articles and six books [Plant Biomechanics 1992, Plant Allometry 1994, The Evolutionary Biology of Plants 1997, Plant Physics (co-authored with Hanns‚ÄìChristof Spatz) 2012, Plant Evolution 2016, and The Origins of Life (co-authored with Thomas Owens and Randy Wayne)]. 

Niklas is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, the Institute of Advanced Study at the Wissenschaftskolleg in Berlin, and the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Wow, what a subject! I've always been facinated, like most of us science nerds, with dinosaurs, sharks, apes, and big cats, but I realized how important plants were to life on earth so I reached out to Dr. Niklas and asked him if he'd be willing to discuss the topic.

More about Dr. Niklas can be found using these links:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karl_J._Niklas
https://www.amazon.com/stores/Karl-J.-Niklas/author/B001IXTUUO
https://cals.cornell.edu/karl-niklas

title: Understanding The Outsider Test for Faith. Michael Beverly Podcast
description:
#otf #counterapologetics 

Support the Channel here:
https://www.patreon.com/michaelbeverly

My links:
michaelsbeverly.com


Join me as I talk with John Loftus about his book The Outsider Test for Faith: How to Know Which Religion is True

https://www.amazon.com/Outsider-Test-Faith-Which-Religion/dp/1616147377

John can be found blogging here:
https://www.debunking-christianity.com/

About the book:

Depending on how one defines religion, there are at least thousands of religions in the world. 

Given such religious diversity, how can any one religion claim to know the truth?

Nothing proposed so far has helped us settle which of these religions, if any, are true--until now. 

Author John W. Loftus, a former minister turned atheist, argues we would all be better off if we viewed any religion--including our own--from the informed skepticism of an outsider, a nonbeliever. 

For this reason he has devised "the outsider test for faith." He describes it as a variation on the Golden Rule: "Do unto your own faith what you do to other faiths." 

Essentially, this means applying the same skepticism to our own beliefs as we do to the beliefs of other faiths.

 Loftus notes that research from psychology, anthropology, sociology, and neuroscience goes a long way toward explaining why the human race has produced so many belief systems, why religion is culturally dependent, and how religion evolved in the first place. 

It's important that people understand these findings to escape the dangerous delusion that any one religion represents the only truth.

At a time when the vast diversity of human belief systems is accessible to all, the outsider test for faith offers a rational means for fostering mutual understanding.

Kim Mark Lewis was a Christian from the age of 13 until the age of 58.

He accepted Christ in a small Christian Missionary Alliance church located in Sonoma California. At the age of 19 he attended Simpson College, now Simpson University, where he received a B.A. in Biblical Literature with a Christian Education minor. After graduation he worked at Simpson‚Äôs library as a Librarian Technician for six years.

His dream was to become a Biblical scholar and study the Bible he did, yet coming from a Fundamentalist world and watching the controversy of Thomas Gundry‚Äôs commentary on Matthew in which he used redaction criticism was unbecoming of an Evangelical.

As a result, the drumbeats of many to oust Thomas Gundry from his teaching position and from the Evangelical Theological Society because of his commentary on the Gospel of Matthew. Kim knew that this was not the path for him to take.

In 1988, Kim left Simpson University to work for his uncle as a software developer. Today he remains a software developer, and his passion for the Bible has not ceased. 

That passion caused him to spend eight years writing his book How John Wrote the Book of Revelation: From Concept to Publication, which as its name implies it describes how the Book of Revelation was written.

Crazy beliefs that Kim Lewis held:

¬∑         The belief that I had the entirety of scripture figured out.

¬∑         Evolution is a lie. The usual tropes just are not as sophisticated as today.

¬∑         Original Sin is not in the Bible.

¬∑         Inerrancy of scripture and the many mental gymnastics involved with the belief.

¬∑         Young Earth Creationists until the age of 50.

¬∑         The rapture is the which occurs prior to the second coming.

 

Today he is an atheist.


Book:

title: Why do Alisa Childers & Tim Barnett Slander, Lie, & Misrepresent Deconstructing Christians?
description:
#apologetics #christianity #atheist #counterapologetics #alisachilders #timbarnett 

Alisa and Tim have been on a book tour for their forthcoming book, The Deconstruction of Christianity, due to be released on January 30, 2024.

In this video I go through their statements and show how they lie about, slander, libel, and misrepresent deconstruction.

They advocate a faulty means of obtaining truth, i.e. they claim that truth can only be obtained if you're "grounded in scripture," which is to argue you must agree to their version of absolute truth before you even start asking questions. 

Clips for this video come from their appearance on Melissa Dougherty's channel, @MelissaDougherty 

https://youtu.be/SLaiALbe5CI?si=afr_GxL1we0M4b0H

Alisa Childers' channel:
@alisachilders 
Tim Barnett's channel:
@RedPenLogic 

For reference, I mention this other video I did regarding Alisa Childers' aversion to truthfulness:
https://youtu.be/lQ6221f0DCw?si=iGhpelbX6y11i8om

Ultimately, if you believe truth is important and truth-seeking is a worthy path to be trodding on in this life, you must have a good methodology.

Tim Barnett, Alisa Childers, and their host in the video sample, Melissa Dougherty do not advocate a good, sound, and healthy epistemology but rather advocate that you have to accept their version of Christianity and their version of the Judeo-Christian Scripture BEFORE you begin the search for truth if you want to obtain it.

Their assertion is not only to recommend a bad method, but they also shame, condemn, and slander/libel those who don't accept it.

Imagine if a different kind of apologist claimed, "You can only know truth if you first accept the Book of Mormon or the Quran or the Vedas as ABSOLUTE TRUTH before you start your inquiry!" 

Please see the pinned comment for timestamps.

One of the most revealing is when Alisa Childers lies about @SeanMcDowell 

You can't make this stuff up, but you can expose it and fight against it.

Please help me spread this message.

If you're a Christian struggling with your faith, it's totally fine to read the Bible, pray, meditate, seek the Lord, and ask for counsel from people you trust, BUT if you're interested in truth, you must have a good methodology and that means you cannot have a bunch of presuppositions and dogmatic truths you accept BEFORE you even start asking questions.

If you can't steelman the skeptics and you're just parroting Christian apologists, you don't actually know anything. 

Respect yourself enough to become a truth-seeker who is willing to be surprised by what you find.

title: Were The Acts of the Apostles inspired by Euripides' The Bacchae?
description:
#apologetics #christianity #atheist #counterapologetics #actsoftheapostles 

Are there undeniable parallels between Acts and The Bacchae? 

It is hard to deny when you hear or see them side-by-side. 

Many Christians find the idea silly and dismiss it out of hand. The problem is that they expect a "parallel" to be an exact match, instead of what they really are, copies of mythemes, tropes, conventions, and scenes.

Is the modern teen-vampire bestselling novel, Twilight, not based or inspired on Bram Stoker's work, because the vampires depicted in Forks aren't the same as those written about in Dracula? 

No, of course not. We know Stephenie Meyer was influenced by vampire lore and didn't invent the idea herself. Obviously.

So when we see parallels in the Gospels and Acts to Euripides, why should we create a double standard for analyzing how fiction is created? 

We should not. 

"But it's not fiction," the Christian apologist claims.

"Oh, yeah?" I answer. "Then why does it copy fiction over and over?"

title: The Last Temptation of Odysseus AI Video Trailer
description:
Does The Gospel of Mark use Homer's Odyssey?

_Let's compare Odyssey 9 & 10 with Mark 5:1-20 and find out!_ 

#apologetics #atheist #christianity #athiesm #counterapologetics 

#aimovie #movietrailer 

Technology used:  Midjourney, Runway, ElevenLabs, D-ID, and ChatGPT 4.

Bible quotes from the King James version.

Note: Before you conclude the comparison isn't exact, so therefore it's not there, remember, writers don't usually or necessarily just straight plagiarize when using material as an inspiration or source.

Writers use classics and popular books as guides and inspiration for the tropes, themes, obligatory scenes, conventions, setups, and so forth.

As an example, if you read (or watch the movie) GREEN MILE, and discover an innocent man, condemned to death, who can do miracles, who's initials are "JC," you don't think, "Oh, Stephen King got the details wrong," nor do you say, "it's entirely coincidental."

No, you conclude the OBVIOUS:

Stephen King was inspired by the New Testament character of Jesus Christ and created John Coffey and his story.

Thus, the same conclusion makes sense here. The writer of Mark was trained in classical Greek writing and OF COURSE he was familiar with HOMER, just like if you wanted to become a (popular) thriller writer today you'd be familiar with Dan Brown and James Patterson.

So, did the scene in Mark 5 really happen?

Odds are no, it's a fictional account of Jesus doing some stuff that is heroic, like Odysseus (only better). To think otherwise is to imagine a boat load of coincidences (pun intended) AND also to think Jesus sailed across the "sea" (really a lake) just to heal this madman and then get right back into his boat again. It's convenient, sure, to think this, but real life isn't so neatly packaged (like fiction is).

Reference:
Mythologizing Jesus: From Jewish Teacher to Epic Hero
The Homeric Epics and the Gospels of Mark
both books by Dennis R MacDonald

NOTE:  This trailer is meant as ENTERTAINMENT and not a highly researched doctrinal thesis, any mistakes are my own, and should not reflect on others' work and/or any of the conclusions or theories found in MacDonald's work.

Shout out to @MythVisionPodcast for helping to make this material more broadly recognized.
